resources.string:
MOD - Maximum Operating Depth
      SAC - Surface Air Consumption
        EAD - Equivalent Air Depth
          END - Equivalent Narcotic Depth
            NDL - No Decompression Limit
              TOD - Theoretical Ocean Depth
                You will find more information inside each of the calculators.

The Surface Air Consumption is an expression of your air consumption during the dive at sea (surface) level. As we all know, air consumption increases with depth because pressure increases, which reduces the volume of the gas, increasing the density of the air we breathe (as per Boyle’s Law).
    Why is it important to know your SAC?
    The two things that determine our bottom time are the breathing gas used and the No Decompression Limits (NDL). So you will surely need to know how much breathing gas you will need for a dive and that is why you need to calculate your SAC rate. Knowing the average depth of the dive (AVG) and the SAC, we can calculate the minimum gas that we are going to need, from there we can choose the volume of our tank and/or modify the dive plan.

    What Is A Good SAC Rate?
    There is no such thing as a good or bad SAC rate as this will differ between diver to diver. On average a new diver may equate a 25 or 27 litres per minute but a relaxed and experienced diver may equate 15 to 18 litres per minute.
      What Affects SAC Rate?
      -Stress
      -Exertion
      -Physical shape
      -Buoyancy
      -Breathing
      -Coldness
        How Can I Decrease My SAC Rate?
        Dive more to get more experience, better buoyancy, reduce stress and exertion. Stay in good physical shape, which improves oxygen consumption and improves breathing. Wear a suitable suit, so as not to get cold throughout the dive.

The Maximum Operating Depth is a depth limit based on the percentage of oxygen in a diver\'s breathing gas. With the higher concentration of oxygen in the gas, the lower will be the maximum depth.
    Why Should a Diver Calculate a MOD?
    Oxygen becomes toxic with depth, the higher the percentage of oxygen in the breathing gas, the lower the depth at which it becomes toxic.
      What happens if I exceed the MOD limit?
      Excessive doses of oxygen at high partial pressures can cause CNS toxicity and pulmonary intoxication.

      CNS toxicity is a toxic effect that can cause seizures (drowning). Its predictability is limited and survival is low.
        Symptoms CNS toxicity may include:
        - Seizures
        - Tunnel vision
        - Auditory noises
        - Nausea
        - Tics
        - Dizziness
        - Irritability

The Equivalent Air Depth is a way of approximating the decompression requirements of breathing gas mixtures that contain nitrogen and oxygen in different proportions to those in air, known as nitrox.
    The equivalent air depth, for a given nitrox mix and depth, is the depth of a dive when breathing air that would have the same partial pressure of nitrogen. So, for example, a gas mix containing 36% oxygen (EAN36) being used at 27 metres (89 ft) has an EAD of 20 metres (66 ft).
      This calculator is about calculating decompression using nitrox. For calculating narcotic effects using trimix, use END calculator (Equivalent narcotic depth).

The Equivalent Narcotic Depth is used in technical diving as a way of estimating the narcotic effect of a breathing gas mixture, such as heliox and trimix.
    The method is, for a given mix and depth, to calculate the depth which would produce the same narcotic effect as when breathing air. It is recommended not to exceed END of 30m.
      Narcosis symptoms:
      - Marked impairment of intellectual capacity
      - Degradation of neuromuscular performance
      - Impaired ability to make sound decisions
      - Impaired consciousness (short-term memory loss, visual impairment)
      - Increased sensitivity to stress
% of oxygen in the gas mixture
The safety stop at sea level
Activate when the water is salty
